results.title: Wide pastures
results.creator_credit: Robert Kingsbury, Eric Thompson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Australia’s most enduring industry is the development, breeding and grazing of the Australian merino sheep. A pastoral revolution based on land clearing, top-dressing and irrigation is increasing sheep production over vast new areas, but the traditional outback has hardly changed since farmers went inland to find sheep country.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Kingsbury, Eric Thompson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Where are we heading
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Gil Brealey, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Dept of Health
results.brief_description: Presents an open-ended look at the effects that different parental attitudes to life and the family unit have on adolescents. Directed mainly at adult audiences, especially parents and community leaders. Note: Restricted to tertiary institutions, teaching hospitals, police and customs departments.

results.title: When will the birds return
results.creator_credit: John Carter, Peter Johnson, Bob Kingsbury and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A television special that takes a long and searching look at the devastation of the city of Darwin in Australia’s Northern Territory after Cyclone Tracy on 25th december 1974. The city became the site of possibly the greatest natural disaster in the nation’s history causing the mass evacuation south of three-quarters of the city’s 43,000 people. The film looks at the results of the cyclone and the spirit of the people of Darwin, determined to rebuild their city.

results.title: Whatever happened to Green Valley?
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Anthony Buckley and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Green Valley, a Housing Commission estate 25 miles west of Sydney, has been subjected to harsh criticism over the years by sections of the media. Supplied with Film Australia equipment, the residents were invited to show themselves and their daily lives. The core of the film is the work of half a dozen Valley residents who selected the subject matter, filmed it, and supervised its editing.

results.title: Week-end fishing = Weekend fishing
results.brief_description: A look at the various forms of fishing in Australia, from the crowded piers in Sydney harbour, to the quiet backwaters, inland streams, and rocky surf beaches. Men and women, young and old, participate in the recreation hoping to enjoy the fruits of their labour at their evening meal.

results.title: Viewpoint on Hobart
results.creator_credit: Barry Williams, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The city of Hobart, Tasmania, as seen through the eyes of European migrants. This film expresses accounts of prejudice and discrimination as well as the advantages of living in Hobart. Also included are brief sequences showing varied aspects of life around the city.

results.title: Viewpoint on Brisbane
results.creator_credit: Barry Williams, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The city of Brisbane, Queensland, as seen through the eyes of European migrants. Language presents more than a communication barrier to the new arrival. It is both a handicap at work and in impediment socially. Criticism is made of officials who do not advise migrants to learn English before landing in Australia. Also discusses the easy going life style of the Queenslanders.

results.title: Valley of the Yarra
results.creator_credit: Maslyn Williams and Australia. Dept. of the Interior. Film Division
results.brief_description: Follows the Yarra River from its source in the mountains to the busy port where it joins Port Phillip Bay. Stresses the importance of the Yarra in the supply of water for Melbourne. Shows farmlands and towns, landscapes and scenery along the river as it goes through to Melbourne.

results.title: Facts
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Union Communication”.
A change in working hours upsets the workers at a factory and Dixon, the Union delegate, is asked to report the change to the union office. In his report to the organiser, Dixon manages to bring in all sorts of irrelevancies but is very short on accurate information. This film manages to pinpoint an area of possible confusion if union delegates fail to get the facts straight.
